content: Spoiler Alert: All right. WTF? That just don't make no sense. Why after all that, would you walk off and leave your only family member ostensibly forever? If Galactica finds Earth 150,000 years ago... If there were humans left in the colonies... And if they let all the "tin cans" go free... And if the Original series has them find Earth in 1980... And if the whole point of this series is "God makes sure things happen the same way in cycles... What? Are they trying to say that both series/stories could exist? Very sad show. I started watching when first deployed in 2004. Five years later the only thing I come away with is this: During those five years at some point, the Colonial Fleet ran out of ammo, water, food, oxygen, patience, humanity, time and faith. But they never, ever seemed to run short of booze or people who'd **** each other, or **** each other over at the drop of a hat. Hollywood dresses up like soldiers but still ends up telling a story about itself.

And if the whole point of this series is "God makes sure things happen the same way in cycles... What? Are they trying to say that both series/stories could exist? Very sad show. I started watching when first deployed in 2004. Five years later the only thing I come away with is this: During those five years at some point, the Colonial Fleet ran out of ammo, water, food, oxygen, patience, humanity, time and faith. But they never, ever seemed to run short of booze or people who'd **** each other, or **** each other over at the drop of a hat. Hollywood dresses up like soldiers but still ends up telling a story about itself.
title: Battlestar Galactica

content: quote: Originally posted by taxiday: I've never been able to get into the new BSG and I forced myself to watch it last night (there was not a d****d thing else worthwhile on TV) and found it as stupid as ever. I think the Bashier(sp?) guy should've been shot 500 episodes ago) and the skinny blonde does nothing but show off her falsies. Ohhh it's all so on the edge and out there. The two most evil characters in the beginning (Skinny blonde-breaks newborn baby's neck out of curiousity) and "Bashier" (actually Bashier was the Doc from Star Trek Deep Space 9, this guy looks like him but it's a different actor)or "Baltar" (guy who sells out the entire human race for nookie) end up being God's angels. All the heroes are discovered to be slime balls. It's all humanity's fault. God guides everybody's actions, good and evil are man's invention. Ooooooh the edgy duplicity of it all. I'd make a smart ass remark about Shakespeare having told it all before if Homer hadn't told it before him . And so much of the series was thinly masked propaganda concerning 9/11, Iraq, torture, military atrocity, global warming....gimme a break. And definitely, definitely never enough "Battle" in Battlestar Galactica. Dig the old TA-1 sound powered phones they used to communicate on the ship.

All the heroes are discovered to be slime balls. It's all humanity's fault. God guides everybody's actions, good and evil are man's invention. Ooooooh the edgy duplicity of it all. title: Battlestar Galactica

content: Spoiler Alert: All right. WTF? That just don't make no sense. Why after all that, would you walk off and leave your only family member ostensibly forever? If Galactica finds Earth 150,000 years ago... If there were humans left in the colonies... And if they let all the "tin cans" go free... And if the Original series has them find Earth in 1980... And if the whole point of this series is "God makes sure things happen the same way in cycles... What? Are they trying to say that both series/stories could exist? Very sad show. I started watching when first deployed in 2004. Five years later the only thing I come away with is this: During those five years at some point, the Colonial Fleet ran out of ammo, water, food, oxygen, patience, humanity, time and faith. But they never, ever seemed to run short of booze or people who'd **** each other, or **** each other over at the drop of a hat. Hollywood dresses up like soldiers but still ends up telling a story about itself.

content: I watched the original series back in 1979 and thought it was a weak, belated copy of Star Trek with a good measure of Star Wars thrown in. If I were to give it a letter grade it would have been a D. I haven't watched the current series. Got better things to do...

content: quote: Originally posted by taxiday: I've never been able to get into the new BSG and I forced myself to watch it last night (there was not a d****d thing else worthwhile on TV) and found it as stupid as ever. I think the Bashier(sp?) guy should've been shot 500 episodes ago) and the skinny blonde does nothing but show off her falsies. Ohhh it's all so on the edge and out there. The two most evil characters in the beginning (Skinny blonde-breaks newborn baby's neck out of curiousity) and "Bashier" (actually Bashier was the Doc from Star Trek Deep Space 9, this guy looks like him but it's a different actor)or "Baltar" (guy who sells out the entire human race for nookie) end up being God's angels. All the heroes are discovered to be slime balls. It's all humanity's fault. God guides everybody's actions, good and evil are man's invention. Ooooooh the edgy duplicity of it all. I'd make a smart ass remark about Shakespeare having told it all before if Homer hadn't told it before him . And so much of the series was thinly masked propaganda concerning 9/11, Iraq, torture, military atrocity, global warming....gimme a break. And definitely, definitely never enough "Battle" in Battlestar Galactica. Dig the old TA-1 sound powered phones they used to communicate on the ship.
